articles.headline: ISIS Lieutenant Emerges From Australian Red-Light District
articles.snippet: A phone call said to have been made by Mohammad Ali Baryalei, a former Sydney bouncer who is now a leader in the Islamic State, set off a counterterrorism crackdown in Australia.
articles.abstract: A phone call said to have been made by Mohammad Ali Baryalei, a former Sydney bouncer who is now a leader in the Islamic State, set off a counterterrorism crackdown in Australia.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In Kings Cross, this city’s bawdy, alcohol-infused red-light district, Mohammad Ali Baryalei once patrolled the sidewalk outside the Love Machine club, his basso voice luring customers in, his muscle keeping the unwanted out. For a time, the police said, his was a world of prostitutes, drugs, gangs and gambling.

articles.headline: Love Them or Loathe Them, Reverse Mortgages Have a Place
articles.snippet: As more people enter retirement with modest savings and no private pension, they are going to need some of the equity they have built up in their homes.
articles.abstract: As more people enter retirement with modest savings and no private pension, they are going to need some of the equity they have built up in their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives from reverse mortgage companies know plenty about consumers’ feelings around inheritance. After all, they’re in the business of encouraging older Americans to drain equity now from homes they may pass on to their heirs in the future.

articles.headline: In London, Houseboats Offer Alternative to High Rent, but New Problems Emerge
articles.snippet: As rents skyrocket, canal homes are proliferating, putting berths at a premium and stretching the existing support system.
articles.abstract: As rents skyrocket, canal homes are proliferating, putting berths at a premium and stretching the existing support system.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the Little Venice neighborhood of west London, the boats’ names appear as colorful as their paint does. The crimson Mayflower bobs in front of the dark green Esmeralda, not far from the navy blue Globetrotter, moored behind the violet Hobbit.

articles.headline: Tougher Shield for Soldiers Against Predatory Lenders
articles.snippet: Loopholes in a law have left hundreds of thousands of service members across the country vulnerable to potentially predatory loans.
articles.abstract: Loopholes in a law have left hundreds of thousands of service members across the country vulnerable to potentially predatory loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is proposing sweeping changes to a seven-year-old federal law that was intended to shield service members and their families from high-cost loans tied to their paychecks, a move that reflects the Defense Department’s growing recognition that lenders have exploited loopholes in the law.

articles.headline: Colorado’s Perceived Left Turn Puts Governor in Tight Race
articles.snippet: Gov. John W. Hickenlooper and his opponent, Bob Beauprez, are trying to appeal to urban and rural voters who are split ideologically.
articles.abstract: Gov. John W. Hickenlooper and his opponent, Bob Beauprez, are trying to appeal to urban and rural voters who are split ideologically.
articles.lead_paragraph: JULESBURG, Colo. — When a Democratic mayor and former brewpub owner named John W. Hickenlooper was elected governor four years ago, he did it with support from voters like Mark Turner. Mr. Turner is a gun dealer, a small-town politician in eastern Colorado and an avowed enemy of partisan labels — “Just call me an American,” he says. He liked Mr. Hickenlooper’s wonky centrism and positive campaigning style.

articles.headline: Signaling Post-Snowden Era, New iPhone Locks Out N.S.A.
articles.snippet: The new iPhone creates a unique code that scrambles information, disrupting the investigative abilities of American law enforcement and intelligence agencies.
articles.abstract: The new iPhone creates a unique code that scrambles information, disrupting the investigative abilities of American law enforcement and intelligence agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Devoted customers of Apple products these days worry about whether the new iPhone 6 will bend in their jean pockets. The National Security Agency and the nation’s law enforcement agencies have a different concern: that the smartphone is the first of a post-Snowden generation of equipment that will disrupt their investigative abilities.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Court Casts a New Light on a Bailout
articles.snippet: From the moment the New York Fed orchestrated the A.I.G. deal, the government has worked hard to keep its full picture from coming into view.
articles.abstract: From the moment the New York Fed orchestrated the A.I.G. deal, the government has worked hard to keep its full picture from coming into view.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I think by the time we get finished with this case and we have our trial, we’re going to have the full picture on everything that occurred regarding the government’s rescue of A.I.G.,” said Thomas C. Wheeler, a federal judge. “Why did they do it the way they did here?”

articles.headline: Long Shots Loom as Spoilers in Tight November Races Across Nation
articles.snippet: The outcome of an unusually large number of Senate and governor’s races this fall could be determined by the outsize role of third-party candidates.
articles.abstract: The outcome of an unusually large number of Senate and governor’s races this fall could be determined by the outsize role of third-party candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an election year shaped by voter anger toward the political establishment, the outcome of an unusually large number of close Senate and governor’s races could be determined by the outsize role of third-party candidates.

articles.headline: Turkey Inching Toward Alliance With U.S. in Syria Conflict
articles.snippet: Turkey is caught between conflicting interests: defeating Islamic militants across its border with Syria while not strengthening Kurdish separatists inside Turkey.
articles.abstract: Turkey is caught between conflicting interests: defeating Islamic militants across its border with Syria while not strengthening Kurdish separatists inside Turkey.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACA, Turkey — No American ally is closer to the threat of the Islamic State than Turkey, and no country could play a more important role in a coalition that President Obama is assembling to combat the extremist Sunni militants. Yet Turkey has been reluctant to enlist, in part because of the desperate conflict playing out on its border with Syria.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Benefits of Joining the Herd
articles.snippet: The Adirondack Grazers Cooperative, based in upstate New York, markets and sells beef for its 36 members. But it also provides hope at a time family farms are rapidly vanishing.
articles.abstract: The Adirondack Grazers Cooperative, based in upstate New York, markets and sells beef for its 36 members. But it also provides hope at a time family farms are rapidly vanishing.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was time for the running of the bulls.

articles.headline: The Unrepentant Bootlegger
articles.snippet: Hana Beshara was a founder of NinjaVideo,  one of the most popular online sites for illegal TV and movie downloads. To the online community, she was its queen. To the government, she was simply a thief.
articles.abstract: Hana Beshara was a founder of NinjaVideo,  one of the most popular online sites for illegal TV and movie downloads. To the online community, she was its queen. To the government, she was simply a thief.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in the morning of June 30, 2010, Hana Beshara woke to a sharp rapping on the door of her condo in East Brunswick, N.J.

articles.headline: As Music Row Shifts to Condo Row, Nashville Cries in Its Beer
articles.snippet: An artist manager and others are working to save the studio where Dolly Parton recorded “Jolene,” a space scheduled to be leveled to make room for condos.
articles.abstract: An artist manager and others are working to save the studio where Dolly Parton recorded “Jolene,” a space scheduled to be leveled to make room for condos.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — To bolster his argument that the cavernous and almost-famous music room known as RCA Studio A should be spared from the wrecking ball, Mike Kopp, an artist manager, dropped a needle onto an LP, playing one of the thousands of songs recorded here over the last half-century.

articles.headline: Today’s Police Put On a Gun and a Camera
articles.snippet: With citizens’ videos of confrontations with the law proliferating, more police agencies are equipping officers to record their version of events.
articles.abstract: With citizens’ videos of confrontations with the law proliferating, more police agencies are equipping officers to record their version of events.
articles.lead_paragraph: PULLMAN, Wash. — Amateur videos of police officers doing their jobs have become part of the fabric of urban democracy, with embarrassing or violent images spreading via social media in minutes.

articles.headline:
Private Bank Fuels
Fortunes of Putin’s
Inner Circle
articles.snippet: The rise of Bank Rossiya, controlled by close friends of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, illustrates how he has enriched loyalists whose influence over the economy has helped him maintain his iron grip on power.
articles.abstract: The rise of Bank Rossiya, controlled by close friends of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, illustrates how he has enriched loyalists whose influence over the economy has helped him maintain his iron grip on power.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Weeks after President Vladimir V. Putin annexed Crimea in March, an obscure regulatory board in Moscow known as the Market Council convened inside an office tower not far from the Kremlin to discuss the country’s wholesale electricity market. It is a colossal business, worth 2 percent of Russia’s gross domestic product, and a rich source of fees for the bank that had long held the exclusive right to service it.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Jo Becker and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: Crackdown on Protests by Hong Kong Police Draws More to the Streets
articles.snippet: Downtown Hong Kong turned into a battlefield of tear gas and seething crowds on Sunday after the police moved against a student democracy protest.
articles.abstract: Downtown Hong Kong turned into a battlefield of tear gas and seething crowds on Sunday after the police moved against a student democracy protest.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Downtown Hong Kong turned into a battlefield of tear gas and seething crowds on Sunday after the police moved against a student democracy protest, inciting public fury that brought tens of thousands of people onto the streets of a city long known as a stable financial center.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Alan Wong

articles.headline: With Perspective From Both Sides of His Desk, F.C.C. Chairman Ponders Net Neutrality
articles.snippet: Tom Wheeler spent decades as a lobbyist for the cable and wireless industries, experience from which he has drawn in creating highly scrutinized policy guidelines for ensuring equal access to online content.
articles.abstract: Tom Wheeler spent decades as a lobbyist for the cable and wireless industries, experience from which he has drawn in creating highly scrutinized policy guidelines for ensuring equal access to online content.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a lobbyist for the cable and wireless industries, Tom Wheeler played a role in shaping almost every major telecommunications policy and innovation over the last three decades.

articles.headline: Growling by Comcast May Bring Tighter Leash
articles.snippet: Regardless of the company’s motive, the issues it raised are hugely important and won’t be brushed aside by bombast or counterattack.
articles.abstract: Regardless of the company’s motive, the issues it raised are hugely important and won’t be brushed aside by bombast or counterattack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Comcast has a long corporate tradition of smiling and wearing beige no matter what kind of criticisms are hurled at it. That public posture is in keeping with the low-key approach favored by Brian L. Roberts, the company’s chief executive, as he seeks to take over the world. It’s worked very well so far.

articles.headline: Iraq Army Woos Deserters Back to War on ISIS
articles.snippet: The Iraqi military command has launched a campaign to re-enlist soldiers and officers who abandoned their units.
articles.abstract: The Iraqi military command has launched a campaign to re-enlist soldiers and officers who abandoned their units.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUSH TAPA, Iraq — The Iraqi military command has begun a campaign to re-enlist soldiers and officers who abandoned their units, a crucial step in its effort to rebuild an army that has been routed in battle after battle by Islamic State jihadists.

articles.headline: You Call This Thai Food? The Robotic Taster Will Be the Judge
articles.snippet: A boxy contraption scans food samples to produce a chemical signature, which it measures against a standard deemed to be that of authentic Thai food.
articles.abstract: A boxy contraption scans food samples to produce a chemical signature, which it measures against a standard deemed to be that of authentic Thai food.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Hopscotching the globe as Thailand’s prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra repeatedly encountered a distressing problem: bad Thai food.

articles.headline: New Yorker’s Magazine Covers Shift From Polite to Provocative
articles.snippet: For most of its existence, the magazine specialized in covers that were calmly reflective and artistic, but they have turned timely, political and poignant.
articles.abstract: For most of its existence, the magazine specialized in covers that were calmly reflective and artistic, but they have turned timely, political and poignant.
articles.lead_paragraph: As scandals engulfed the National Football League, The New Yorker magazine’s cover that appeared on newsstands last week showed a player being chased down the field by police officers.

articles.headline: Mostly Black Cities, Mostly White City Halls
articles.snippet: Disparities between the percentage of black residents and the number of black elected officials are facts of life in scores of American cities, particularly in the South.
articles.abstract: Disparities between the percentage of black residents and the number of black elected officials are facts of life in scores of American cities, particularly in the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONYERS, Ga. — Since moving to this small city on the eastern flank of Atlanta’s suburban sprawl, Lorna Francis, a hairdresser and a single mother, has found a handsome brick house to rent on a well-groomed cul-de-sac. She has found a good public school for her teenage daughter.

articles.headline: Dire Warnings by Big Tobacco on E-Smoking
articles.snippet: The tobacco industry’s giants are putting health warnings on e-cigarettes that outstrip both those on traditional cigarettes and those on e-cigarettes made by smaller competitors, leaving public health officials skeptical about the companies’ inte...
articles.abstract: The tobacco industry’s giants are putting health warnings on e-cigarettes that outstrip both those on traditional cigarettes and those on e-cigarettes made by smaller competitors, leaving public health officials skeptical about the companies’ intent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tobacco companies, long considered public health enemy No. 1, have suddenly positioned themselves as protectors of consumer well-being in the digital age.

articles.headline: House Hopefuls in G.O.P. Seek Rightward Shift
articles.snippet: In districts where generally mild-mannered Republicans are exiting, their likely replacements may increase division in an already polarized Congress.
articles.abstract: In districts where generally mild-mannered Republicans are exiting, their likely replacements may increase division in an already polarized Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: One nominee proposed reclassifying single parenthood as child abuse. Another suggested that four “blood moons” would herald “world-changing, shaking-type events” and said Islam was not a religion but a “complete geopolitical structure” unworthy of tax exemption. Still another labeled Hillary Rodham Clinton “the Antichrist.”

articles.headline: Spy Agencies Urge Caution on Phone Deal
articles.snippet: An obscure federal contract for routing phone calls and text messages has prompted a lobbying battle in which intelligence officials argue that surveillance secrets could be at risk.
articles.abstract: An obscure federal contract for routing phone calls and text messages has prompted a lobbying battle in which intelligence officials argue that surveillance secrets could be at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An obscure federal contract for a company charged with routing millions of phone calls and text messages in the United States has prompted an unusual lobbying battle in which intelligence officials are arguing that the nation’s surveillance secrets could be at risk.

articles.headline: Literary Lions Unite in Protest Over Amazon’s E-Book Tactics
articles.snippet: Many more writers have signed on to Authors United, a group not only challenging Amazon on its Hachette dealings, but also asking federal authorities to investigate it on antitrust matters.
articles.abstract: Many more writers have signed on to Authors United, a group not only challenging Amazon on its Hachette dealings, but also asking federal authorities to investigate it on antitrust matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The authors are uniting.
